question: Following blunt trauma a young male presents with a D shaped pupil. What is the diagnosis?
exp: Iridodialysis, in which the iris is torn away from its ciliary attachment for a variable distance, occurs more frequently .A black biconvex area is seen at the periphery, and the pupillary edge bulges slightly inwards forming a 'D'-shaped pupil. In a blunt trauma, substance of the iris is often torn. The most common lesions are minute ruptures in the pupillary margin which are of little significance, while radiating lacerations of the iris, sometimes extending to the ciliary margin, are rare. Iridoschisis-This rare condition occurs most commonly as a degenerative ageing senile phenomenon, though it may follow as a late result of severe trauma. Large dehiscences appear on the anterior mesodermal layer of the iris and strands of this tissue may float into the anterior chamber.

question: Which of the following investigation is contraindicated in metallic foreign body
exp: MRI is contraindicated in Metallic intra ocular foreign body due to its magnetic feild . The strong static magnetic field (B0) of MRI scanners can attract and accelerate ferromagnetic objects toward the center of the machine and turn them into dangerous projectiles. This magnetic field can also displace implants or affect the function of devices (pacemakers and pumps),Metallic Implants

question: Which of the following is not an indication of immediate treatment in cases of trauma
exp: Hyphaema is not an indication of immediate treatment, most of the times it resolves on its own Remember Hyphaema in blunt trauma resolves mostly with time, indication of immediate hyphaema drainage are *High IOP for many days on persistent medication (IOP > 25 on MMT for 5 days, > 50 for more than 2 days) *Corneal blood staining *Chances of recurrence high (Sickle cell anemia)

question: A young man presents with history of motorcycle accident resulting in a fall on the head. The only finding is a bruise over the eyebrow. What is he most likely to suffer from?
exp: Traumatic optic neuropathy can occur in trauma over eyebrow(most commonly at the junction of lateral 1/3rd and medial 2/3rd of eyebrow behind which runs the intra canalicular pa of optic nerve). Orbital blow out fracture will cause bruise over lower pa of eye, not eyebrow. Rosette cataract can be seen in trauma but it is not associated with bruise over the eyebrow. Scleral rupture will not occur in trauma occurring at the level of eyebrow.

question: In a patient of head injury, who presents with headache and increased intracranial pressure, the effect on pupil is:
exp: Effect on pupil is ipsilateral mydriasis. - In this patient of head injury bleeding occurs, which increases Intra cranial pressure- This increased intra cranial pressure compresses and damages the 3rd nerve- 3rd nerve carry the parasympathetic fibers which is responsible for pupillary constriction- So, the unopposed sympathetic fibers mediated by the 5th nerve dilate the pupil - Hence patient comes with ipsilateral mydriasis Hutchinson's pupil is an ipsilateral mydriasis due to 3rd cranial nerve compression by an intracranial mass lesion including intracranial bleeds

question: True about acid injury to eye are all except?
exp: Chemical injuries of the eye may be divided into 2 types 1. Acid injuries (Burns)- less destructive--> coagulate and precipitate proteins--> create a barrier and prevent fuher penetration (Except- Hydrofluoric acid--> fluoride ions penetrate into deep tissues --> more damage) Ground glass apparance 2. Alkali injuries- severe, they are lipophilic--> saponification of memebrane lipids--> tissues undergo liquefactive necrosis + release of proteolytic enzymes--> damage Mx - Immediate Irrigation with normal saline (even water if normal saline not available) for minimum 30 mins, pH of conjunctiva must be 7-7.2. Chemical debris can be removed by double eversion Rx- Topical antibiotics (Grade I-III injuries- erythromycin /Grade IV- moxi/gatifloxacin) Cycloplegics (atropine/homatropine) Topical steroids (prednisolone acteate - 10days, tapered by 14 days based on clinical response) Doxycyline (-) MMP Antiglaucoma drugs to avoid secondary glaucoma Vitamin C Tear supplements Other Mx options - Autologous serum, Amniotic membrane transplantation (AMT), mucous membrane graft, Conjunctival flaps
opa: makes a barrier and prevent deeper penetration
opc: steroids are used to control inflammation
opd: glaucoma is most preventable complication following acid injury

question: Blow out fracture of orbit commonly involves:-
exp: Blow out fracture of orbit Floor is involved first M.C fracture of orbit Force of blow cause a rise in intraorbital pressure with resultant fracture at the weakest point of orbital wall which is floor. THOUGH medial wall is thinnest but it is suppoed by ethmoid air cells which absorb pressure , thus it is not the most commonly fractured wall. Entrapment of inferior rectus in inferior wall fracture = not able to look up Features 1. Enophthalmous 2. Diplopia 3. Infra orbital nerve anesthesia
opb: Medial wall is involved first as it is the thinnest
opc: The patient is not able to look up due to superior rectus palsy
opd: Roof is involved first as it bears the maximum impact
